attracts.title: MEDAL OF HONOR INFORMATION CENTER
attracts.subtitle: Presented by Pueblo Home of Heroes Association

puebloRecipientsDetail.title: Medal of Honor Recipients
puebloRecipientsDetail.description: Pueblo's four Medal of Honor recipients represent three wars. William Crawford, World War II, Carl Sitter and Raymond (Jerry) Murphy, Korean War and Drew Dix, Vietnam. Their incredibly heroic exploits are representative of the over 16,000 veteran's that call Pueblo their hometown and the local culture that nurtured their character such that they would be willing to put their life in mortal danger to save their fellow soldiers.

puebloRecipients.name: William J. Crawford
puebloRecipients.hallfame_image_caption: William J. Crawford receives Medal of Honor from President Ronald Reagan at USAF Academy graduation 1984
puebloRecipients.light_display_text: The uniform jacket in this display is one actually worn by Mr. Crawford and donated by him for this display. All patches, badges, award ribbons and medals were designated by him to be displayed on his jacket.
puebloRecipients.bio: Pvt. Bill Crawford was a squad scout in action with the enemy near Altavilla, Italy, 13 September 1943, when his Company was attacked on Hill 424 by an enemy-held position. After reaching the crest of a hill, his platoon was pinned down by intense enemy machine-gun and small-arms fire. Locating one of these guns, which was dug in on a terrace on his immediate front, Pvt. Crawford, without orders and on his own initiative moved over the hill under enemy fire to a point within a few yards of the gun emplacement and singlehandedly destroyed the machine gun and killed three of the crew with a hand grenade, thus enabling his platoon to continue its advance. When the platoon, after reaching the crest, was once more delayed by enemy fire, Pvt. Crawford again, in the face of intense fire, advanced directly to the front midway between two hostile machine-gun nests located on a higher terrace and emplaced in a small ravine. Moving first to the left, with a grenade he destroyed one gun emplacement and killed the crew; he then worked his way, under continuous fire, to the other and with one grenade and the use of his rifle, killed one enemy and forced the remainder to flee. Seizing the enemy machine gun, he fired on the withdrawing Germans and facilitated his company's advance.

puebloRecipients.name: Carl L. Sitter
puebloRecipients.hallfame_image_caption: Carl Sitter receives his Medal of Honor from President Harry S. Truman in 1951
puebloRecipients.light_display_text: The uniform jacket in this display is one actually worn by Mr. Sitter and donated by him for this display. All patches, badges, award ribbons and medals were designated by him to be displayed on his jacket.
puebloRecipients.bio: Ordered to break through enemy-infested territory to reinforce his battalion 29 November 1950, Capt. Sitter continuously exposed himself to enemy fire as he led his company forward and, despite 25 percent casualties, succeeded in driving through to his objective. He reorganized his depleted units the following morning and led them up a steep frozen hillside under blistering fire, encouraging his troops as casualties occurred and directing forward platoons to drive to the top of the ridge. The enemy launched a vicious counterattack, setting the hill ablaze with mortar and machine-gun fire taking a heavy toll in troops. Capt. Sitter visited each foxhole, deploying reinforcing units consisting of service personnel unfamiliar with infantry tactics into a combat team instilling in every man the determination to hold his position at all costs. With the enemy penetrating his lines in counterattacks requiring hand-to-hand combat, and infiltrating to the command post with hand grenades, he fought gallantly with his men in repulsing and killing the fanatic attackers in each encounter. Painfully wounded in the face, arms, and chest by bursting grenades he refused to be evacuated and continued to fight on until a successful defense of the area was assured. His valiant leadership and superb tactics throughout 36 hours of bitter combat reflect the highest credit upon Capt. Sitter and the U.S. Naval Service.

summary.name: Unit/Command
summary.value: Company G, 3D Battalion, 1ST Marines, 1ST Marine Division (Rein)

summary.name: Presentation Date
summary.value: October 29, 1951, the White House, Presented by Pres. Harry S. Truman

summary.value: December 2, 1922, Syracuse, Morgan County, MO, United States

summary.name: Buried

puebloRecipients.name: Raymond G. Murphy
puebloRecipients.hallfame_image_caption: Raymond G. Murphy receives his Medal of Honor from President Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1953
puebloRecipients.light_display_text: The uniform jacket in this display is one actually worn by Mr. Murphy and donated by him for this display. All patches, badges, award ribbons and medals were designated by him to be displayed on his jacket.
puebloRecipients.bio: While serving in Korea 2d Lt. Murphy, although painfully wounded by fragments from an enemy mortar shell, steadfastly refused medical aid and continued to lead his men up a hill through a withering barrage of hostile mortar and small-arms fire, skillfully maneuvering his force and shouting words of encouragement. Undeterred by the increasing intense enemy fire, he located casualties as they fell and made several trips up and down the fire-swept hill to direct evacuation teams to the wounded, personally carrying many of the stricken marines to safety. With all the wounded evacuated, he remained behind to cover the movement of friendly forces off the hill. After reaching the base of the hill, he organized a search party for a final check on missing marines, locating and carrying the bodies of a machine-gun crew down the hill. Wounded a second time through a continuing barrage of enemy small-arms, artillery, and mortar fire, he again refused medical assistance until assured that every one of his men, including all casualties, had preceded him to the main lines. His resolute and inspiring leadership, exceptional fortitude, and great personal valor reflect the highest credit upon 2d Lt. Murphy and enhance the finest traditions of the U.S. Naval Service.

puebloRecipients.name: Drew D. Dix
puebloRecipients.hallfame_image_caption: Drew D.Dix receives his Medal of Honor from President Lyndon B. Johnson in 1969
puebloRecipients.light_display_text: The uniform jacket in this display is replica of one worn by Mr. Dix. All of Mr. Dix military memorabilia were destroyed in a fire during the time he lived and worked in Alaska. All patches, badges, award ribbons and medals were designated by him to be displayed on his jacket.
puebloRecipients.bio: S/Sgt. Dix distinguished himself by exceptional heroism while serving as a unit adviser. Two heavily armed Viet Cong battalions attacked the Province capital city of Chau Phu. S/Sgt. Dix, with a patrol of Vietnamese soldiers, was recalled to assist in the defense of Chau Phu. Learning that a nurse was trapped in a house near the center of the city, S/Sgt. Dix organized a relief force, successfully rescued the nurse, and returned her to safety. Being informed of other trapped civilians within the city, S/Sgt. Dix voluntarily led another force to rescue 8 civilian employees located in a building which was under heavy mortar and small-arms fire. S/Sgt. Upon approaching a building, he was subjected to intense automatic rifle and machine gun fire. He personally assaulted the building, killing 6 Viet Cong, and rescuing 2 Filipinos. The following day he assembled a 20-man force and under intense enemy fire cleared the Viet Cong out of the hotel, theater, and other buildings within the city. He then attacked enemy troops who had entered the residence of the Deputy Province Chief and rescued the official's wife and children. S/Sgt. Dix's heroic actions resulted in 14 confirmed Viet Cong killed in action, the capture of 20 prisoners, and the rescue of the 14 civilians. The heroism of S/Sgt. Dix was in the highest tradition and reflects great credit upon the U.S. Army.

summary.name: Unit/Command
summary.value: Senior Advisor Group, IV Corps, U.S. Military Assistance Command

pages.title: Medal of Honor Memorial
pages.description:
Pueblo bronze artist David Dirrim and granite artist William Yates, both Colorado natives, were selected in 1998 to create the Pueblo Medal of Honor Memorial to be placed outside the Convention Center on Medal of Honor Plaza in the year 2000. In addition to the statues of Pueblo's four heroes and the names of all of the over 3,500 recipients were incorporated on granite plaques mounted on the walls of the Convention Center just behind the sculptures. Listed by war, the names are in alphabetical order.

Other features are a 35-foot flagpole in the center of a granite bench seating area. The words of President Dwight Eisenhower are engraved on the side of the bench to remind us of his words upon placing the Medal of Honor around Raymond "Jerry" Murphy's neck. He said: "What is it in the water out there in Pueblo, all you guys turn out to be heroes?".

pages.title: Home of Heroes
pages.description: Pueblo, Colorado is proud to claim four Medal of Honor recipients as having grown up in our community and in the late 1990's we were the only city in the U.S. to have four living recipients out of the approximately 150 living at the time. This rare distinction, along with the fact that we have more veteran's per capita than any city in Colorado, led to Pueblo being called the Home of Heroes.

media.title: Tom Brokaw

As Pueblo West was created a street was named for Joe Martinez, a Medal of Honor recipient from Alt, Colorado. He was the first Hispanic recipient of the award. His local relatives in Pueblo are pictured with his portrait, dedicated the first day of the 2000 Congressional Medal of Honor Society's convention in Pueblo.

pages.title:
History of the
Medal of Honor
pages.description: The Medal of Honor is the United States' highest award for military valor in action. And, while over 150 years have passed since its inception, the meaning behind the Medal has never tarnished. Etched within the Medal are the very values that each Recipient displayed in the moments that mattered—bravery, courage, sacrifice, integrity and a deep love of country plus a desire to always do what is right at the risk of one’s life.

media.title: Short History of the Medal of Honor

slides.caption: The Medal of Honor is the highest award for valor in action against an enemy force that can be bestowed upon an individual serving in the armed forces of the United States It is generally presented to its recipient  by the President of the United States in the name of Congress.

The Congressional Medal of Honor Society of the United States of America is perhaps the most exclusive organization in our country. It is certainly one of the most unique. Its small membership includes men of all races, social classes, and economic levels. No amount of money, power, or influence can buy one's rite of passage into this circle and, unlike almost any other organization, this group's members hope that there will be no more inductees. Beyond the attitude towards recruitment, about all they have in common is a passionate love for the United States of America and the distinct honor of wearing the nation's highest award for military valor the medal of Honor.

pages.title: Veterans’ Bridge
pages.description:
The “Veterans’ Bridge” is the only monument in the United States recognizing veterans of all military branches and duty statuses. It is also the first time in history that families can group family members who are veterans together regardless of which branch of service they served in, or whether they served in peacetime or war. Veterans are prominently displayed on the bridge along with Pueblo’s four Medal of Honor recipients, the 5 military branch seals, and the flags of both Colorado and the United States.

Veterans’ Bridge Steering Committee Chairman Gus Sandstrom stated, “Pueblo has one of the highest concentrations of veterans in the nation. This bridge will forever honor the sacrifice of the men and women who served our nation. We owe our freedom to their sacrifice.”

“Veterans’ Bridge” is a partnership between the Pueblo Veterans’ Council, the Historic Arkansas Riverwalk of Pueblo Foundation and the Pueblo Home of Heroes Association.

slides.caption: Dedicated November 11, 2010, Veterams Bridge is located on the Historic Arkansas Riverwalk  of Pueblo.  The Veterans' Bridge is a $1.5 million pedestrian footbridge and monument, built throgh a partnership betweeen the Pueblo Veterans Council and the HARP Foundation with the Pueblo Medal of Honor Foundation;s help providing an electronic data base. It was designed to further Pueblo's proud tradition of honoring veterans.
One of two pyramids which hold the names of over 7,000 veterans. Each plaque has the service person's name, branch of the service and dates of service.
One of two pyramids which hold the names of over 7,000 veterans. Each plaque has the service person's name, branch of the service and dates of service.
Each plaque has the service person's name, branch of the service and dates of service.

attractions.name: Center for American Values
attractions.descptn: The Center's organizational mission is based on the need for a national ...
attractions.detail:
The Center's organizational mission is based on the need for a national initiative to identify, document and disseminate information about individuals, groups and organizations whose character attributes relate directly to the values this great country was founded upon. The Center displays an extraordinary collection of photographic portraits and documentation of over 140 Congressional Medal of Honor recipients. The collection is a powerful example of the self-sacrifice one segment of our society has made to protect the freedoms we enjoy.

101 S. Main Street
719-543-9502
attractions.qrcode_label: Scan QR code for map location

videos.title: Civil War Medal of Honor Display

attractions.name: Weisbrod Aircraft Museum
attractions.descptn: The Pueblo Weisbrod Aircraft Museum is a non-profit aviation museum ...
attractions.detail:
The Pueblo Weisbrod Aircraft Museum is a non-profit aviation museum located in near Pueblo Air Port. It was founded in the mid-1970s by former Pueblo City Manager Fred Weisbrod. The museum is made up of two hangars that were built in 2005 and 2011. The hangars house dozens of the museum's aircraft of all kinds with thousands of artifacts dating from World War I to modern day.

640 Pueblo Reservoir Road 81006
719-561-9320
attractions.qrcode_label: Scan QR code for map location

attractions.name: Historic Arkansas Riverwalk of Pueblo
attractions.descptn: Less than a block from the Pueblo Convention Center is the Historic ...
attractions.detail:
Less than a block from the Pueblo Convention Center is the Historic Arkansas Riverwalk of Pueblo. This 26 acre, urban, water based, multigenerational recreational environmental education park is publicly owned and free of charge to all populations within the region. In the past the Arkansas River was the dividing line between the US territory and Mexico and the Riverwalk has the flags of five nations which have flown over the area (France, Spain, Mexico, Texas and US).. For a small fee excursion boats are available with a boat captain who will point out many of the the sculptures, some out in the open and others which are hidden away, as you learn more about Pueblo.

101 S. Union Avenue 81003
719-595-0242
attractions.qrcode_label: Scan QR code for map location

attractions.name: Sangre de Cristo Arts and Conference Center
attractions.descptn: This three building complex is located in the heart of downtown ...
attractions.detail:
This three building complex is located in the heart of downtown Pueblo. It is dedicated to the dissemination of art and culture in this part of Colorado. The center was founded in 1972 and in the past 50 years has been a major driving force in development of art and dance. The structures inside the complex comprises a theater which has a seating capacity for 500 spectators, Buell Children’s Museum and art galleries. Besides hosting cultural events and national and international art exhibits, the center also conducts classes and programs all through the year.

210 N. Santa Fe Avenue
719-283-3623
attractions.qrcode_label: Scan QR code for map location

attractions.name: El Pueblo History Museum
attractions.descptn: The El Pueblo History Museum is one block from the Convention Center ...
attractions.detail:
The El Pueblo History Museum is one block from the Convention Center and the Riverwalk. Fort Pueblo was founded in 1842 on the Arkansas River - which divided the United States from Mexico. El Pueblo was an important cultural crossroads of the Southwest. Here lived Anglo, French, and African-American trappers and traders; Mexican settlers and their families; and Plains, Iroquois, Delaware, and Cherokee Indians. The occupants traded, farmed, and ranched in and around this combination trading post and settlement. Made of adobe, the post and its living quarters, were built around a secure interior plaza.

301 N. Union Avenue 81003
719- 583-0453
attractions.qrcode_label: Scan QR code for map location

attractions.name: Pueblo Heritage Museum
attractions.descptn: The Southeastern Colorado Heritage Center preserves and furthers the ...
attractions.detail:
The Southeastern Colorado Heritage Center preserves and furthers the local culture, while keeping the history of the place alive. They have on display, memorabilia from the city's history and culture leading up to the present day. Exhibits include, Pueblo's 1921 Flood, Early Coloradoans, Depression Era, Telephones through the years, Sewing machines, Pueblo Saddles, just to name a few.

201 W. B Street 81003
719-295-1517
attractions.qrcode_label: Scan QR code for map location

attractions.name: Military Monuments and Memorials
attractions.descptn: Pueblo has many unique monuments, memorials, attractions, and ...
attractions.detail: Pueblo has many unique monuments, memorials, attractions, and recreation areas you will enjoy. Through the years, Veterans from every era have been honored in some way in the Pueblo area. Unique monuments, memorials, plaques, cannons, signs, parkways, parks, and sculptures dot the landscape. Added in more recent times are highway welcoming signs, the Medal of Honor Plaza, Weisbrod Aircraft Museum, Veterans Bridge, Walk of Valor, and Center for American Values. Pride in our veterans helps make Pueblo the Home of Heroes.

slides.caption: This Colorado Vietnam Memorial was the dream of Delbert Schmeling, a Vietnam Army veteran. It is located  at 26th and North Elizabeth Streets in the Elizabeth Street Parkway. The memorial was dedicated  in 1996 to those from Colorado who served their country during the Vietnam Era 1964-1975 and has the names of the 620 Colorado men and women who gave their lives in service during this conflict.

This bronze plaque, dedicated to the USS Pueblo, its captain  and crew, is at the front door of the Pueblo Convention Center. The USS Pueblo was called an Auxiliary General Environmental Research vessel to hide its true purpose of intelligence gathering. It was named for the city and county of Pueblo. The community followed events closely when it was attacked and seized in 1968 in international waters by North Korea who is still in possession of the ship, making it the only captive vessel on the commissioned roster of the US Navy.The crew was captive for 11 months. Commander Lloyd Bucher visited Pueblo following his release to thank the community for its support and efforts in seeking the men's return. The crew members have met in Pueblo several times since then.

Pueblo City Hall was constructed in 1916 followed by a large city auditorium added at the south end. On September 25, 1919 President Woodrow Wilson came to Pueblo to draw support for the League of Nations, which he felt would help prevent future wars. Needing a large place indoors to hold he speech, the City Auditorium was suggested, even though it was not quite finished. During that speech Wilson dedicated the auditorium as 'Memorial Hall' in honor of those who died in the Great War (WWI).

Welcoming people to Pueblo is a large highway sign proclaiming Pueblo as 'Home of Heroes'. Spanning the decades, Pueblo has had pride for its veterans and has shown it through monuments and memorials.

Drew D. Dix recently saw his namesake street sign change locations. Rather than having a one block road in the Belmont area that leads to a park bearing his name, City Council approved renaming a portion of Platteville Boulevard on the northern edge of the city, to Drew Dix Parkway. Jerry Murphy is honored with a Street in the Belmont area, while both Carl Sitter and Bill Crawford have streets on the south side of Pueblo near the areas where they used to deliver newspapers.

Drew D. Dix recently saw his namesake street sign change locations. Rather than having a one block road in the Belmont area that leads to a park bearing his name, City Council approved renaming a portion of Platteville Boulevard on the northern edge of the city, to Drew Dix Parkway. Jerry Murphy is honored with a Street in the Belmont area, while both Carl Sitter and Bill Crawford have streets on the south side of Pueblo near the areas where they used to deliver newspapers.

Drew D. Dix recently saw his namesake street sign change locations. Rather than having a one block road in the Belmont area that leads to a park bearing his name, City Council approved renaming a portion of Platteville Boulevard on the northern edge of the city, to Drew Dix Parkway. Jerry Murphy is honored with a Street in the Belmont area, while both Carl Sitter and Bill Crawford have streets on the south side of Pueblo near the areas where they used to deliver newspapers.

Drew D. Dix recently saw his namesake street sign change locations. Rather than having a one block road in the Belmont area that leads to a park bearing his name, City Council approved renaming a portion of Platteville Boulevard on the northern edge of the city, to Drew Dix Parkway. Jerry Murphy is honored with a Street in the Belmont area, while both Carl Sitter and Bill Crawford have streets on the south side of Pueblo near the areas where they used to deliver newspapers.

Drew D. Dix Park , named for Pueblo Medal of Honor recipient, is an 8.6 acre park on Massari Road near Troy Avenue. While this park has been in existence for many years it received a much needed improvement of signage and playground area thanks to many Veteran and  volunteer groups.

Located on Pueblo's northside at 29th and Elizabeth Street Parkway, in an area known as Victory Row,  this Doughboy statue was created by the Daughters of American Revolution to remember the World War I. It was titled Ready, but quickly became known simply as The Doughboy
Memorial to the famous 89th Infantry Division, activated in both WWI and WWII and memoralizes all 400 Puebloans who served in the division during WWI and lists 27 who were killed

The USS Maine was sunk during the Spanish American War. The ship was raised, and from the metal recovered this plaque was one of 1,000 cast. Pueblo was allotted one because it is a community that lost officers or crew on the vessel. It represents victory in an attitude of sorrow.
Centennial High School was established in 1873, before Colorado became a state (1876). It has plaques recognizing the four wars in which its students fought and many died.
Mineral Palace Park features a large concrete obelisk dedicated to all soldiers and sailors. Nearby is a 155mm Howitzer cannon used during WWII

Pueblo County Courthouse at 10th & Main Street, is guarded by Lady Liberty. All  branches of service and  veterans groups are  now recognized both outside and inside the building. Lady Liberty was one of more than 200 installed throughout the United States in 1950 by the Boy Scouts of America.

Issac R. French served in the Union Army during the Civil War and came to Pueblo in 1883, joining the Colorado National Guard. Active in local veterans organizations including the Grand  Army of the Republic, he is credited  with this Civil War monument which is by the Federal Building at 5th and Main Streets. Erected in 1902.

This Mormon Battalion monument Located near Runyon Field is in recognition of a detachment of U.S. soldiers who , during the Mexican  War, spent the winter of 1846-47 near the junction of Santa Fe Avenue and Santa Fe Drive. With their families and Mormon immigrants from Mississippi, the settlement numbered around 275, and from it, the first white children in Colorado were born.

Peter.C. Lemon Rose Garden is near the front door of the Pueblo ConventionCenter and is in honor of Medal of Honor recipient Peter C. Lemon (who was living in Colorado Springs),  for all his help and personal dedication to working with young people in our community to learn about leadership, ethics, and patriotism. It also honors the members of Lemon's Battalion who lost their lives in Vietnam.

Pueblo City Hall was constructed in 1916 followed by a large city auditorium added at the south end. On September 25, 1919 President Woodrow Wilson came to Pueblo to draw support for the League of Nations, which he felt would help prevent future wars. Needing a large place indoors to hold he speech, the City Auditorium was suggested, even though it was not quite finished. During that speech Wilson dedicated the auditorium as 'Memorial Hall' in honor of those who died in the Great War (WWI).

An eighty foot flagpole flying Old Glory centers the Southeast Asia Memorial on the CSU-Pueblo campus. It is flanked by a Colorado flag and a POW/MIA flag. The memorial contains granite  slabs bearing the names of those who attended the college and were killed while fighting in Vietnam.

An eighty foot flagpole flying Old Glory centers the Southeast Asia Memorial on the CSU-Pueblo campus. It is flanked by a Colorado flag and a POW/MIA flag. The memorial contains granite  slabs bearing the names of those who attended the college and were killed while fighting in Vietnam.

The Patrick A. Lucero Library, one of the newest branches of the Pueblo City/County Library District is named for an Eastside native who gave his life serving in the Vietnam War. It was dedicated on September 24, 2013 at 7th and Monument Streets.

Pueblo Central High School on Orman Avenue is the second oldest High School in Pueblo and thought to be the only high school in America to graduate two Medal of Honor recipients  William J. 'Bill' Crawford and Carl. L. Sitter  and it recognizes them as such with a display case in their main hallway. Also at Central High is a plaque honoring the memory of former students who died in World War II.

Pueblo Community College,  formerly Pueblo Junior College, has a plaque in memory of alumni and employees who served in conflicts and deployment throughout the world from its founding in 1933 through the end of World War II.
Imperial Memorial Gardens cemetery has established a Veterans Court of Honor and is known for its ceremonial handling of military funerals.

Near the main entrance to Pueblo West, is a plaza that honors all its residents who have served in the Armed Forces. The Community also honors another Medal of Honor recipient Joseph P 'Joe'. Martinez . A resident of Alt, Colorado, Martinez has many relatives in Pueblo. He became the first Hispanic American to receive the Medal of Honor during World War II.
The largest display of patriotism in the entire area is found at Roselawn Cemetery, where the tributes date back to the Civil War.

attractions.name: Charles Goodnight Barn
attractions.descptn: The original barn of cattleman legend Charles Goodnight has ...
attractions.detail:
The original barn of cattleman legend Charles Goodnight has been renovated to show what life on the early frontier was like. Taking cattle from Texas to the Dakotas in the 1800's was hard work. Goodnight, along with partner Oliver Loving made many trips. Goodnight established a ranch here in the Pueblo area. The cattle barn is the only piece of that ranch that is left. Over the last few years it has been refurbished and is available for special uses by appointment only. Bronze sculptures of both Goodnight and Loving can be found along the Pueblo Riverwalk in downtown Pueblo.

5475 W. State Hwy 96 81005

attractions.name: Lake Pueblo State Park
attractions.descptn: Lake Pueblo (also known as Pueblo Reservoir) has a maximum depth ...
attractions.detail:
Lake Pueblo (also known as Pueblo Reservoir) has a maximum depth of 135 feet (41 m) and is impounded by Pueblo Dam. It includes 60 miles (97 km) of shoreline and 10,000 acres (40 km2) of land. Activities it offers include two full-service marinas, recreational fishing, hiking, camping and swimming at a special swim beach. Lake Pueblo is host to many water recreation activities including sailing, motor-boating, waterskiing, wakeboarding, wake-surfing, river tubing and prime fishing.

640 Pueblo Reservoir Road 81005
719-561-9320

attractions.name: Nature & Wildlife Discovery Center Mountain Campus
attractions.descptn: The Nature and Wildlife Discovery Center is a multi-campus ...
attractions.detail:
The Nature and Wildlife Discovery Center is a multi-campus nature preserve and educational center in Pueblo County. The NWDC which includes a 611 acres (247 ha) mountain park, lodge, gift shop, and museum in Beulah, a small museum and educational center, as well as an open-space park on the Arkansas River in Pueblo and an adjacent raptor education and rehabilitation facility.

Nature and Wildlife Discovery Center:
5200 Nature Center Drive 81005, 719-549-2414

Pueblo Mountain Park:
9112 Mountain Park Drive, Beulah, 719-485-4444

attractions.name: Pueblo City Park and Zoo
attractions.descptn: Located in the City Park in Pueblo, the Pueblo Zoo houses ...
attractions.detail:
Located in the City Park in Pueblo, the Pueblo Zoo houses about 420 animals of 140 species. The areas of the park are divided into different parts based on the animals housed like the Serengeti Safari, North American Grasslands and many more. City park has fountains, a lake, tennis courts, a skate park, frisbee golf, a dog park, and acres of grass and trees for picnic area as well as a swimming pool.

5200 Nature Center Drive 81005
719-549-2414
